awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Enhancing Teacher Knowledge & Skills in Modern Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This new three-year Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site Program, Enhancing Teacher Knowledge and Skills in Modern Manufacturing, at Texas A&M University (TAMU) will enhance the knowledge and skill-level of a diverse cohort of middle and high school teachers with limited access to research opportunities, in both traditional and advanced manufacturing. Though Texas had a manufacturing output of $232.2B or 15.2% of the gross state product (in 2014), it had only 7.6% of its workforce in manufacturing. Advanced manufacturing development is facing a serious shortage of qualified personnel stemming from a lack of student interest. Many middle/high schools are limited in their growth of technology, robotics, or SkillsUSA programs due to budget constraints and/or lack of technical expertise among teachers. It is necessary to reverse this trend by providing infrastructure and manufacturing expertise to teachers, so that young students are inspired to join engineering and technology programs and choose STEM careers. This site is a direct response to such concerns, generating a motivated workforce well-rooted in manufacturing knowledge/skills, fuse research with education activities at the middle and high schools, motivate students for higher education, and build long-term collaborative partnerships in the region.

Each summer, a group of 12 teachers (a total of 36 teachers over 3-years) will be hosted at TAMU for 6 weeks, where they will immerse in hands-on research experiences in both traditional and advanced manufacturing, specifically in the areas of (i) processes, (ii) materials, and (iii) metrology techniques. The on-site experience will be supplemented with integration and follow-up visits at their respective home institutions, as well as regular status updates. While at TAMU, these teachers will take part in capsulated technical sessions, complementary lab practice, field tours, research seminars, and guided research projects. Deliverables will include an implementation lesson and lab plan, as well as dissemination of the developed curriculum at annual teacher summits. The target school districts are near TAMU, focusing on those in rural areas, or those with a large number of under-represented students. This program is supported by local, state, and national-level industries and professional societies. The expected outcomes of this program will be the transfer of knowledge and skills to excite, empower, and educate students through new class/lab activities. This will enable and inspire students to effectively participate in science/engineering projects and pursue STEM/manufacturing careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this RET site was to enhance the knowledge and skill-level of middle and high school teachers in both traditional and advanced manufacturing, specifically in (i) manufacturing processes, (ii) materials and (iii) metrology techniques. For this, a group of 8-12-teachers/year (both in-service and pre-service) were hosted at the campus of Texas A&M University (TAMU) for 6 weeks each summer. This on-site experience was supplemented with integration/follow-up visits at their respective home institutions, as well as regular status updates. During the on-site period, these teachers took part in capsulated technical sessions, complementary lab practice, tours, seminars, and guided research projects within a design thinking framework. During the follow-up years, meetings among the teachers, school officers, PI/Co-PI and industry were conducted to ensure successful implementation. The deliverables from the on-site program included an implementation classroom lesson and laboratory activity plan, as well as dissemination of newly acquired knowledge at annual teacher summits. The target school districts are those near TAMU, especially those in rural areas, and/or with a large number of underrepresented students. Recruitment efforts used several channels to select dedicated middle/high schoolteachers: TAMU and NSF websites, existing TAMU programs, invitation letters, and presentations by the PI/Co-PI at targeted schools while encouraging participation from women, minorities, and persons with disabilities. Program success metrics included tracking the resulting number of students in science/engineering clubs at participating schools, number of students entering technical/engineering programs after high school, their success at regional/national competitions, etc. 

Over the project duration, a total of forty (40) pre-service and in-service teachers whose home institutions spanned the state of Texas were recruited into impactful training and research experiences at TAMU. Considering site performance, an external evaluator developed pre- and post-program surveys to assess the extent to which original program goals were met as well as overall progress in project implementation efforts. Overall, the project was well-received by participants, reached its goal number of participating teachers, exposed teachers to cutting edge technologies, and provided space to develop relevant curriculum for diverse students. However, the implementation of high quality, design-based manufacturing projects was somewhat low since some of the teachers retired, which others changed schools or did not have the time to follow up; COVID-19 and its aftereffects had an impact in hampering the implementation efforts as well.

Altogether, the core outcome of this program was the effective transfer of the teacher-acquired practical knowledge/skills onto their students via new class/laboratory activities; this enabled and inspired them to effectively participate in science/engineering projects. Thus, the program benefited society by helping to create an empowered future workforce well rooted in manufacturing knowledge/skills, fuse research with education activities at the middle/high school levels, motivate underrepresented students to pursue STEM education/careers and build long-term collaborative partnerships with regional educational institutions and industries.
